<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.3 is: Controlling expressions shall not be invariant.
Here are exceptions to this rule:
1. Invariants that are used to create infinite loops are permitted.
2. A do-while loop with an essentially Boolean controlling expression that evaluates to false and satisfies the constraints and semantics for an integer constant expression is permitted.
</misra_rule>

DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.

<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_init:
```c
int metal_init(const struct metal_init_params *params)
{
	int error = 0;

	if (_metal.common.ref_count++ != 0)
		return 0;

	memset(&_metal, 0, sizeof(_metal));

	_metal.common.log_handler   = params->log_handler;
	_metal.common.log_level     = params->log_level;

	metal_list_init(&_metal.common.bus_list);
	metal_list_init(&_metal.common.generic_shmem_list);
	metal_list_init(&_metal.common.generic_device_list);

	error = metal_sys_init(params);
	if (error)
		return error;

	++_metal.common.ref_count;
	return error;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: Only controlling expressions are relevant for MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.3. In the provided function the only control statements are the two if statements listed above. There are no for/while/do-while loop controlling expressions or other conditional expressions in this function to consider. Other lines (variable declarations/initialization, memset, assignments, function calls, and the final increment) are not controlling expressions and thus are not subject to Rule 14.3; they do not need investigation for this specific rule.
